hedline.hl1: The Neediest Cases; Newborns A Blessing And a Trial For a Family

abstract.p: Rosalyn Utti, Nigerian immigrant faced with huge costs after giving birth to triplets, one of whom died, is aided by Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of seven New York charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)

block.p: Rosalyn Utti was ecstatic in the spring of 1997 when she found out she was pregnant. But when the sonogram showed she was carrying triplets, she feared that maybe it was too much of a good thing.
She remembered how difficult and expensive it had been for her mother to raise two sets of twin boys in her village in Nigeria.
Rosalyn Utti was ecstatic in the spring of 1997 when she found out she was pregnant. But when the sonogram showed she was carrying triplets, she feared that maybe it was too much of a good thing.
She remembered how difficult and expensive it had been for her mother to raise two sets of twin boys in her village in Nigeria.

At 34, living in Brooklyn with few relatives nearby, Mrs. Utti could not imagine how she would afford to care for her own children. Although she was college-educated and had been a nurse in Nigeria, Mrs. Utti was still waiting for her working papers four years after she had moved to the United States.

Her husband, Luke, had been here since 1979, and worked full time as a case manager for mentally ill patients at the Institute for Community Living. But his salary barely covered the costs of feeding their young son, Obi, and the rent on their apartment.
After carrying the children for 21 weeks, Mrs. Utti suffered from premature contractions and had to spend six weeks at Kings County Hospital.
On Nov. 8, 1997, doctors performed a Caesarean section, and Rosalyn, Shirley and Vivian entered the world. Together, the triplets weighed almost as much as one healthy baby.
Shirley and Vivian gradually gained weight and went home after six weeks, but Rosalyn never did. She died at the age of two months without ever having left the incubator.
While they coped with Rosalyn's death, the Uttis had to find ways to support their living children.

So, like other new parents, the Uttis gathered their resources to provide for their expanded family. But the Uttis had to buy twice as many supplies as typical parents. The challenge was formidable, but they were not discouraged.
''I knew that with hard work, we'd find a way,'' Mr. Utti said.
Mrs. Utti shopped carefully and Mr. Utti took on an extra shift at work, adding the midnight to 8 A.M. shift on Sundays to his regular hours.
Still, the family did not have enough money.

One of Mr. Utti's co-workers saw the strain on his face, and gave him the phone number for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the seven New York charities supported by The New York Times
Neediest Cases Fund.
The federation, which coordinates the charitable efforts of 260 agencies in New York City, helps people work through emergency situations so that they can support themselves once more.

Once the Uttis documented their problems and demonstrated that they would be able to provide for their family in the future, the federation used $800 from the Neediest Cases Fund to buy two crib sets and a double stroller, said Judy Milone, director of client services.
''That young family was psychologically overwhelmed by the loss of a child,'' Ms. Milone said, ''and financially overwhelmed by a multiple birth, and we were glad to be able to help.''

Mrs. Utti said: ''I was so grateful. I had no idea how we were going to survive.'' Not only did the family survive, it thrived. Shirley and Vivian developed at a steady rate, crawling at six months and trying to stand before their first birthday.
And though the Uttis are still struggling financially, they say they feel encouraged.
''I am confident,'' said Mr. Utti, ''that one day we will be helping others.''
